Award.AbstractNarration: Abstract<br/><br/>Award: DMS-0803193<br/>Principal Investigator: Yongbin Ruan<br/><br/>During the past twenty years, there has been a great deal of<br/>interaction between mathematics and physics. An important area of<br/>this interaction involves the theory of Gromov-Witten<br/>invariants. In physics, it counts the instantons corrections of<br/>Calabi-Yau space. In mathematics, it provides important<br/>invariants for algebraic and symplectic geometry. Inspired by<br/>both mathematics and physics, Gromov-Witten theory has been<br/>established in a variety of situations such as relative<br/>Gromov-Witten theory and orbifold Gromov-Witten theory. Each of<br/>them is an integral part of the big picture and they have been<br/>essential for a complete understanding of Gromov-Witten<br/>theory. This proposal seeks to advance Gromov-Witten theory in<br/>two directions; (i) expanding Gromov-Witten theory to the<br/>Landau-Ginzburg/singularities model and developing it as an<br/>effective computational tool for ordinary Gromov-Witten theory;<br/>(ii) applying Gromov-Witten theory to study symplectic birational<br/>geometry.<br/><br/>Mathematics is always an important tool and language in our<br/>understanding of the structure of the universe we live in. In<br/>the string theoretic model of the universe, modern mathematical<br/>subjects such as geometry and topology play an ever bigger<br/>role. In particular, Gromov-Witten invariants enter these models<br/>as important physical quantities called instanton<br/>corrections. This project will improve our ability to calculate<br/>instanton corrections and hence enhance our understanding of the<br/>possible structure of the universe.<br/>
